summary: This document is a summary from the Public Corruption Unit detailing significant developments in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It notes her indictment on June 29, 2020, her arrest on July 2, 2020, and the scheduling of her trial for November 29, 2021. It highlights key pretrial rulings, including allowing victims to testify anonymously.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Charged by a grand jury for her role in facilitating Jeffrey Epstein's abuse of minor girls. Arrested and detained, with trial scheduled.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the individual whose abuse of minor girls Maxwell facilitated.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the Maxwell case who has ruled on significant pretrial motions, including allowing victims to testify anonymously.

connections.description: Maxwell is charged with facilitating Epstein's abuse of minor girls, indicating a collaborative criminal relationship.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judicial officer in Maxwell's criminal case, ruling on pretrial motions.

events.title: Grand Jury Indictment of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: A grand jury returned a six-count indictment charging Ghislaine Maxwell for her role in facilitating Jeffrey Epstein's abuse of minor girls.

events.title: Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested at a residence in New Hampshire.

events.title: Scheduled Trial of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Trial for Ghislaine Maxwell was scheduled to begin on this date.

events.title: Pretrial Motion Ruling on Victim Anonymity
events.description: Judge Nathan ruled that victims in the Maxwell case could testify anonymously, increasing their willingness to participate.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was indicted on June 29, 2020, on six counts related to facilitating Jeffrey Epstein's abuse of minor girls.
Maxwell was arrested on July 2, 2020, at a residence in New Hampshire and has been detained since.
Her trial was scheduled for November 29, 2021, with significant pretrial motion activity.
Judge Nathan ruled that victims could testify anonymously, a critical decision for witness cooperation.
